learning_outcomes.description: Formulate an engineering problem from a limited brief
Apply project management techniques to plan and carry out a small engineering research project in the allocated time frame, within the available resources, and in a safe and ethical manner
Generate appropriate evidence through a reproducible method that is suitable for drawing sound conclusions
Evaluate critically the outcomes of your research
Develop evidence-based arguments to support conclusions
Explain your ideas effectively to a general audience by using effective audio-visual means.
Report the rationale and findings in a written document

assessments.task_description:
Students must prepare a report that includes the following sections:

  • Introduction – Provide background information on the research topic, identify the key issues to be investigated, and explain the importance of addressing these issues.
  • Literature Review – Critically analyse existing literature relevant to the research topic, summarise previous work, and highlight opportunities for improvement in future studies. From this analysis, identify the main research questions and clearly state the study’s objectives, which should aim to address these questions.
  • Research Plan – Describe the methodology and approach for executing the project. Incorporate a Gantt chart to visually present the project timetable.
  • Work to Date – Summarise the progress achieved so far, using text, figures, and tables as appropriate.
  • Health and Safety (Optional) – If the project involves fieldwork or laboratory activities, provide a list of required risk assessments and safety inductions.
  • References – List all sources cited in the report.
  • Appendices (Optional) – Include supplementary materials, such as spreadsheets, computer code, or other relevant data.

This task is intentionally challenging, authentic, and complex. While students may utilise AI and/or machine translation technologies, successful completion of the assessment will require critical engagement with specific contexts and tasks, where artificial intelligence can offer only limited support and guidance.

Failure to reference the use of generative AI or machine translation may be considered student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students must demonstrate a thorough understanding of their written submission independently of AI and machine translation tools.

The report should be approximately 15 pages in length, not including the table of contents, references, or appendices.

assessments.task_description:
Students are required to present their work to a non-specialist audience, including examiners, within the designated timeframe. The exact date and allocated times will be announced on Blackboard. The presentation should address the following points:

  • Aims and background
  • Research gaps and objectives
  • Methodology
  • Results
  • Conclusions

The presentation must not exceed 10 minutes; you may be asked to stop if you go over time. A 9-minute Q&A session will follow each presentation, with one minute allocated for changing presenters.

Presentation slides must be uploaded one day prior to the first presentation, in accordance with the submission instructions posted on Blackboard.

Whilst AI may be used in the slides preparation, students are required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their work, independent of AI and MT tools, during the oral presentation and the following Q&A session.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The presentation slides (<100Mb) must be uploaded to Turnitin.

assessments.task_description:
The Final Report can reuse the structure and content from the Progress Report.

Students must prepare a report that includes the following sections:

  • Abstract – Summarise the research background, gaps, methodology, key findings, conclusions, and implications. The abstract should be concise and informative, enabling readers to understand the report’s essence without reading the full document.
  • Introduction – Provide background information on the research topic, identify the key issues to be investigated, and explain the importance of addressing these issues.
  • Literature Review – Critically analyse existing literature relevant to the research topic, summarise previous work, and highlight opportunities for improvement in future studies. Based on this analysis, identify the main research questions and clearly state the study’s objectives, which should address these questions.
  • Research Methods – Outline the research tools employed (e.g., fieldwork, laboratory experiments, mathematical modelling, or databases). Describe, in your own words, the procedures followed during the study (e.g., experimental steps, data collection before and after processes). Include solutions implemented to resolve issues encountered during the research.
  • Results and Discussion – Present your findings clearly using text, figures, and tables as appropriate. Summarize key results and, where relevant, compare your findings with those of previous studies.
  • Conclusion – Summarize the background, methodology, key findings, and implications of your study. The conclusion should reflect on the significance of your research, any limitations, and potential directions for future work.
  • References – List all sources cited in the report.
  • Appendices (Optional) – Include supplementary materials such as spreadsheets, computer code, or other relevant data.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.

The report should be approximately 30 pages in length, not including the table of contents, references, or appendices.
